author: Dan O'Donoghue
title: Newcastle to house 80 refugee families from war-torn Syria
text:
Newcastle to house 80 refugee families from war-torn Syria 11:30, 27 Jul 2016 The pledge comes as the city council is expected to reaffirm its commitment to refugees, asylum seekers and former Afghani interpreters Shares Get daily news by email 2015 Getty Images Refugees wait to pass through a Greek police cordon before crossing the Greek-Macedonian border on December 4, 2015 near the village of Idomeni, Greece 
Newcastle has reaffirmed its commitment to refugees - by pledging to take 20 Syrian families a year up until 2020. 
Since Syria was plunged into civil war some five years ago, 4.8 million people have been displaced - with half of those affected being children. 
Newcastle was one of the first cities to respond to the British Government’s call for local authorities to offer support to resettle vulnerable Syrian refugees and to date 15 families - 73 people - have moved into the city. 
In addition to Syrian refugees, the city has taken in more than 200 asylum seekers in the last year, up from 540 in April 2015 to 751 in April this year. 
Asylum seekers are mainly settled in Elswick, Benwell, Scotswood and Byker. G4S has started to directly procure properties to accommodate asylum seekers in the city and will be managing these. 
Newcastle also continues to support 20 households under the Government’s Afghanistan resettlement scheme. 
The scheme resettles ex-Ministry of Defence interpreters from Afghanistan to the UK, most of whom would have been at risk had they remained in the Middle East. Ten Afghani interpreters have been settled in the city this month. 
Councillor Joyce McCarty, deputy leader of Newcastle City Council , is expected to tell councillors on Thursday that the city will continue to welcome refugees for the next four years. Joyce McCarty, deputy council leader at Newcastle City Council 
She will say: “This year has seen the worst refugee crisis since World War Two and Europe has seemed overwhelmed by the number of people, displaced by war and conflict, seeking safety. 
“I am proud that Newcastle, as a City of Sanctuary, has been able to respond to this crisis proactively.” 
Since the Syrian civil war began, as many as 386,000 people have been killed, including nearly 14,000 children, says the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. Read More What Newcastle is doing to help desperate refugees fleeing their war-torn country 
And Coun McCarty will continue: “This support is about more than just offering a place of safety. 
“It is about offering opportunities to participate so that lives can be rebuilt and families can put down roots and make their own valuable contribution to the future of the city.” 
Resettlement costs are being met by central Government, with funding agreed for the next five years. 
Earlier this month the council was forced to condemn the “anti-immigration narrative” which has come to the fore following the EU referendum. 
Liberal Democrat councillor David Faulkner said that those against multiculturalism had been emboldened by the Brexit vote. 
In a bid to tackle the rise in racist abuse, the Government revealed on Tuesday that new watchdogs would be established to assess the police response to hate crime. Dominic Lipinski /PA Wire Amber Rudd 
Amber Rudd, the new Home Secretary, announced plans to commission Her Majesty’s Inspectorate of Constabulary to carry out a “scoping study” into forces’ understanding of and response to hate crime. 
Ms Rudd said: “Those who practise hatred send out a message that it’s OK to abuse and attack others because of their nationality, ethnicity or religious background; that it’s OK to disregard our shared values and promote the intolerance that causes enormous harm to communities and individuals. 
“Well, I have a very clear message for them - we will not stand for it. Hatred has no place whatsoever in a 21st century Great Britain that works for everyone.” More on the EU Referendum
